3AB7B30500A64739B8A3D78FFB30E4CF.description: Show concern for safety in planning, carrying out and reviewing activities (e.g., follow safety regulations for drivers; respect others’ space, materials and work during an activity)

2CFDA5E67C6A4D6B9FE8CF5BE17081D0.description: Demonstrate sensitivity and responsibility in pursuing a balance between the needs of humans and a sustainable environment

B198D6588AEB4915AFBA3A9B020EA742.description: Work collaboratively in planning and carrying out investigations, as well as in generating and evaluating ideas (e.g., help motivate others; listen to the points of view of others)

A87DAD43FA904FD9AF4024588FB99C70.description: Seek and apply evidence when evaluating alternative approaches to investigations, problems and issues (e.g., develop explanations and descriptions about safety issues in transportation)

A5357D049BDF4A789BA6713FC9E00378.description: Appreciate that scientific understanding evolves from the interaction of ideas involving people with different views and backgrounds (e.g., appreciate the benefits that have resulted from a better understanding of the law of conservation of momentum)

AFCB8091DFFF4186826652AF7B5E43A8.description: Show interest in science-related questions and issues, and confidently pursue personal interests and career possibilities within science-related fields (e.g., explore and use a variety of methods and resources to increase their own knowledge and skills related to safety and driving; investigate careers in traffic law enforcement)

CAE0854098A544F4BCB9F4928D9E928A.description: evaluate individual or group processes used in planning, problem solving, decision making and completing a task (e.g., assess group processes used to evaluate cars for their safety features)

554716EE1155445EB962BA834940FC87.description: select and use appropriate numeric, symbolic, graphical and linguistic modes of representation to communicate ideas, plans and results (e.g., create data tables and a summary of questionnaire results; graph results, using appropriate scales)

5F155132EF4848DFBCF344F798C14FEC.description: communicate questions, ideas and intentions; and receive, interpret, understand, support and respond to the ideas of others (e.g., develop a plan to assess the safety features of new cars)

4E23A927D3024113896BC5C2D41767E7.description: Communication and Teamwork: Work collaboratively on problems; and use appropriate language and formats to communicate ideas, procedures and results

192A122EC532483CBF20972F6FCC51D4.description: identify new questions or problems that arise from what was learned (e.g., “What is whiplash, and why is it more common in rear-end collisions?”)

5DA293DC2D5F4051A626732C2E789B12.description: explain how data support or refute the hypothesis or prediction (e.g., investigate the statements: “More traffic accidents occur on Monday mornings.”; “More pedestrians than drivers are killed by cars.”)

8D54F66157EE41D882E74D0C475C32E2.description: identify and explain sources of error and uncertainty in measurement, and express results in a form that acknowledges the degree of uncertainty (e.g., list sources of uncertainty in the measurement of “reaction time,” use SI units and unit analysis to check the results of mathematical solutions)

7FEB64979C3D4332B84AC1365377B336.description: identify and apply criteria; i.e., social factors, explanations, methods, data, related research and relevance, including the presence of bias, for evaluating evidence and sources of information (e.g., identify and analyze a variety of factors that affect the authenticity of information derived from the mass media and electronic communication)

8329CDFB73E54C79BA420AAB3AF301DB.description: interpret patterns and trends in data, and infer or calculate linear or nonlinear relationships among variables (e.g., determine speed [velocity] from a distance–time graph, or distance from a speed [velocity]–time graph)

C0A1D1D27A2A47AEAB7AEADA19CC52B1.description: identify a line of best fit on a scatterplot, and interpolate or extrapolate based on the line of best fit (e.g., graph distance–time relationships)

33213CB142634E819882E86E308383AD.description: compile and display evidence and information, by hand or computer, in a variety of formats, including diagrams, flow charts, tables, graphs and scatterplots (e.g., draw a force–time graph for cushioned and noncushioned toy cars, in an investigation of the effectiveness of different types of cushions for a toy car)

AD54D67721A54EC2BF2334E54930E4DC.description: describe and apply classification systems and nomenclature used in the sciences (e.g., use terms such as force, speed [velocity], impulse, momentum)

E726E306EC0D4822A6C084689B14891D.description: Analyzing and Interpreting: Analyze qualitative and quantitative data, and develop and assess possible explanations

360ACE9E07614897A4A8A714D23B0822.description: compile and organize data, using appropriate formats and data treatments to facilitate interpretation

8302DF6115224D978DFB27E7AEE55AF5.description: compile and organize data, using appropriate formats and data treatments to facilitate interpretation

FA6BFD7B1DC0455796B016D21DDCED4E.description: estimate quantities (e.g., estimate, predict, check and validate calculations)

E6B57273156F4C0F9D0B8841F3BD45A2.description: use instruments effectively and accurately for collecting data (e.g., develop a questionnaire to elicit community opinions about wearing seat belts)

47DE57F635F1487593505CA7AC21A947.description: carry out procedures, controlling the major variables and adapting or extending procedures where required (e.g., test different materials for use as seat belts)

91C354B4E453478EA3EF66C48830A938.description: Performing and Recording: Conduct investigations into the relationships between and among observations, and gather and record qualitative and quantitative data

3607F94D852C445E904921A0B9E8F173.description: evaluate and select appropriate instruments for collecting evidence and appropriate processes for problem solving, inquiry and decision making (e.g., use a force probe and sonic ranger to determine the effectiveness of different types of cushions for a toy vehicle)

77547B16BDCF48A8874B94BD6991E57B.description: formulate operational definitions of major variables (e.g., force, impulse)

6A5708B6DF194D1FBA3AE2812157B546.description: identify the theoretical basis of an investigation, and develop a prediction and a hypothesis that are consistent with the theoretical basis

AECDB1FE2BFB4DEE8636591E215106FC.description: state a prediction and hypothesis based on available evidence and background information

49F0041B2BC445AEBE1D9AB6B0E560F9.description: design an experiment, identifying the manipulated, responding and fixed variables (e.g., investigate how air bags work, using a partially inflated beach ball or plastic bag and a steel ball or rock to model the functioning of the air bag)

71BCDE281FC04D869DF1A4D6CBD26B4C.description: define and delimit problems to facilitate investigation (e.g., determine reaction time)

157EE0F8E3844767AE2FA1A2BBB4DD2E.description: identify questions that arise from practical problems and issues (e.g., “How long does it take to respond to an emergency?”)

5D1A761B29CE41C7A58149694457A5C6.description: Initiating and Planning: Ask questions about relationships between and among observable variables, and plan investigations to address those questions

A66E6B992D484481B16935C85AF36C60.description: describe the application of the law of conservation of momentum in a variety of situations involving two objects (e.g., rear-end collision, recoil, jumping from a boat, traffic accidents, two people on skates pushing each other)

A502C55E7FF0425F8DB4E2CA25A6D853.description: compare the functioning of first and second generation air bags, and explain the need for improving the design of air bags (e.g., first generation air bag design assumed drivers to be adult males, not wearing seat belts; for the second generation design, these assumptions were revised to reduce speed and force of air bag deployment)

E5A34FB971F045B8A8E38FC438E2B71E.description: analyze data or studies comparing vehicle occupant injuries, for belted and unbelted occupants, before and after seat belt legislation

857A222C082E48659C277BC19CF5CA4D.description: illustrate, qualitatively, the application of the concept of impulse to the design of automobile safety features (e.g., dashboards, car bumpers, restraining nets, crash barriers on highways)

F6A5B557858949FB8B7C395A537C6F11.description: explain how seat belts and air bags function in terms of changing momentum and force (e.g., explain why one cannot brace for a collision as a means of protection; explain why babies must be placed in special seats and not on a passenger’s lap)

52C45230F4DD4C3892E69B8E41FC383A.description: Apply the principles underlying the motion of objects to explain the need for safety devices and practices

4891E26D48B84EAFAF7650BC0A1A016D.description: illustrate, quantitatively, the conservation of momentum as the following: the total momentum of two objects before a collision is the same as after the collision when friction is minimal and the two objects lock together

315CF40940D545668145B83F800F8C24.description: analyze the force experienced, using mΔv/Δt = F), if change in momentum (impulse) occurs over a longer or shorter period of time (e.g., stopping an object gradually over a longer period of time reduces the amount of a potentially damaging force, and stopping an object quickly over a shorter period of time increases the amount of a potentially damaging force)

5859A1F987694485BB17D7EC98FBB476.description: define impulse as a change in momentum, and calculate impulse as the product of force and the time interval over which it acts: mΔv = FΔt

D384D5B04D984B3C99066A5FB76BE7CF.description: explain why it takes a large heavy object, such as a train, a great distance to come to a stop

79C3A86892E64034A4431568B3D5FAB5.description: relate the momentum of an object as being directly proportional to its mass and speed (velocity) (e.g., quantify the momentum of an object, using the formula: momentum [kgm/s] = mass [kg] × speed [m/s])

DFD3455026044B0E8B189B65AEC7015E.description: Apply concepts of force, mass and the law of conservation of momentum to investigate one-dimensional collisions of two objects

8414AF5F80F0441FAE0B77875A9FF0CB.description: determine the distance travelled by objects during “reaction time,” when given appropriate data (e.g., by a car when traffic lights turn from yellow to red, by a baseball to a batter, by a puck to a goaltender)

1FC642B5B1F6423FAD9C94F29FE49A09.description: define distance travelled as a product of speed (velocity) and the time interval, and quantify the distance travelled using d = vt (e.g., express distance in metres [m])

49FF924065874F5088B61F2CAF39E0A4.description: plot a distance versus time graph, and use the slope of the graph to determine the speed (velocity) of an object

866151A2B58443898A6D371938A690F6.description: define speed (velocity) as change in position during a time interval, and quantify speed (velocity) using v = d/t (e.g., express speed [velocity] in metres per second [m/s])

09729FC3075E4A06A68D822FA969DBDB.description: Describe the change in position and speed of objects mathematically and graphically

863134B707574CF1A72E5AF2F3A3D14F.description: compare the death and injury rate in motor vehicle accidents to other causes of death and injury among adults and teenagers

8F604BD5D349487798E6531D8F30ACFA.description: identify and analyze the dangers faced by people in a motor vehicle accident

4E594E8A280D4B979BC62A6DF2AF087F.description: list and describe ways that passengers can protect themselves from injury in accidents

C6F1D32F275D4FBF9ABBCA5E32AD45B2.description: list traffic safety factors (e.g., reasons why some traffic lights stay yellow for three seconds and others for five seconds; reasons why some traffic lights have advanced warning flashers; speed bumps; guardrails; reflectors; rumble strips)

1B2C1BCAC96D42E19CC45A932166F29C.description: discuss the consequences of a shorter or longer reaction time

05350026F778486680A6A14C10DFB7A9.description: assess the need for staying a safe distance behind another automobile when travelling at highway speeds (e.g., maintaining a two-second gap under normal driving conditions)

C9B596056F3946F9BB7DF87DFEAE2115.description: list the factors influencing the ability to make sudden stops (e.g., degree of wakefulness, visual acuity, state of mind, ingestion of prescription drugs and/or alcohol)

2B41A921D2024AC786C86E0C56E8A123.description: Use explanatory models from their own learning in science or personal experience to distinguish between scientific and personal opinion and to analyze the need for safety systems and regulations

BF3CB13B4A4644E8B05EBD786714AFDE.description: Outcomes for Science, Technology & Society (STS) & Knowledge

3F75CCD1C4D045828FAED5328E085E46.description: Unit D: Motion, Change & Transportation Safety

EAC7E1946F3D46859F229D29252F7FAA.description: Show concern for safety in planning, carrying out and reviewing activities (e.g., write safety and waste disposal concerns into the laboratory procedure; follow proper food handling and preparation processes when working in the kitchen; show consideration for others when ill, by limiting the exposure of others to pathogens)

4367BFD77209491D99211A62BE806583.description: Demonstrate sensitivity and responsibility in pursuing a balance between the needs of humans and a sustainable environment (e.g., share the responsibility for maintaining clean air and clean water)

EB42A11FB70C4B6CA6474EA8F6EEFAD4.description: Work collaboratively in planning and carrying out investigations, as well as in generating and evaluating ideas (e.g., assume a variety of roles as required; be attentive when others speak)

6E996FF54EE5471F9538DC2A7FFD0858.description: Seek and apply evidence when evaluating alternative approaches to investigations, problems and issues (e.g., insist on evidence before accepting a new idea or explanation; criticize arguments in which evidence, explanations or positions do not reflect the diversity of perspectives that exist)

F09A1DAB22DC466CAC8A3CB3F13D4AA1.description: Appreciate that scientific understanding evolves from the interaction of ideas involving people with different views and backgrounds (e.g., carefully research and openly discuss ethical dilemmas associated with applications of advancements in genetics)

1D39DDE262B646A6BDB70DC2493ADFEB.description: Show interest in science-related questions and issues, and confidently pursue personal interests and career possibilities within science-related fields (e.g., readily investigate health issues; investigate careers, such as practical nurse, ambulance attendant, food and restaurant inspectors)

D37547E9A65D49E7AF28C3DAE2859822.description: evaluate individual and group processes used in planning, problem solving, decision making and completing a task (e.g., assess processes used to determine if the introduction of human genes into other species, such as mice and bacteria, poses a risk to human health)

2207973377B2498FBCB39C2A46BDFFA4.description: work cooperatively with team members to develop and carry out a plan, and troubleshoot problems as they arise (e.g., plan the collection and culturing of different bacteria to measure the effectiveness of antibacterial agents)

DEC8E2070E7F4B51804AF7790BA07B58.description: develop, present and defend a position or course of action, based on findings (e.g., assess, qualitatively, the risks and benefits of cloning plants and animals for agriculture; produce a brochure that explains how to reduce the chances of getting a communicable disease, such as the common cold)

C9CF59552C594EB59E846F87869B8CB9.description: identify multiple perspectives that influence a science-related decision or issue (e.g., consult a wide variety of sources that reflect varied viewpoints on particular topics, such as genetic screening of humans)

7BEF35B615824A7D83D9E2D3AB964B06.description: select and use appropriate numeric, symbolic, graphical and linguistic modes of representation to communicate ideas, plans and results (e.g., create a generalized model of DNA; prepare a visual representation of the method of infection/transmission of a specific human pathogen)

CF288CFB625A4A45B8BBD9EAA9710C27.description: communicate questions, ideas and intentions; and receive, interpret, understand, support and respond to the ideas of others (e.g., participate in a variety of electronic group formats)

F291D9D395B54AA79766DD60F20D1CEC.description: COMMUNICATION AND TEAMWORK: Work collaboratively on problems; and use appropriate language and formats to communicate ideas, procedures and results

5CA9AEA8717F423B89A5B6D4947E8DBB.description: identify and evaluate potential applications of findings (e.g., assess factors that promote or discourage growth in bacteria populations; identify mutagens in the environment and trace their sources)

043F75B488474D3A92C27ECC2B83F1F3.description: identify new questions or problems that arise from what was learned (e.g., “How do bacteria develop resistance to antibacterial agents over time?”)

FD80F59E27E64E3C9928647F02C09D19.description: evaluate the relevance, reliability and adequacy of data and data collection methods (e.g., assess the authority, reliability and validity of electronically-accessed information; assess methods used to determine the spread of infections in a population)

9FCA16B933BC4926920EAD2DA1FADBA0.description: synthesize information from multiple sources or from complex and lengthy texts, and make inferences based on this information (e.g., research how a specific food handling or preparation industry prevents the microbial contamination of their final product; record relevant data for acknowledging sources of information, and cite sources correctly)

798652F2B4744CC28C1CF549962FA168.description: compile and display evidence and information, by hand or computer, in a variety of formats, including diagrams, flow charts, tables, graphs and scatterplots (e.g., graph the incidence of a particular disease over time)

3EAC22DA3D464BA09CAE881339AF9719.description: ANALYZING AND INTERPRETING: Analyze qualitative and quantitative data, and develop and assess possible explanations

DA35C82B453046C4AE3AB49255F8690D.description: select and integrate information from various print and electronic sources (e.g., investigate genetic diseases on the Internet)

1107A48E3DDA460BB096B6C023BD0D6B.description: use library and electronic research tools to collect information on a given topic (e.g., use current, reliable information sources to find out about the spread of diseases, such as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), tuberculosis and cholera)

7AFEB6C905984FD5BE23DF1015928A0F.description: compile and organize data, using appropriate formats and data treatments to facilitate interpretation (e.g., graph results of a simulated spread of infection; track the population growth of bacteria, using spreadsheets)

4FEA3E08C20A43B1BD09314F4DAF1CA6.description: use instruments effectively and accurately for collecting data (e.g., observe prepared slides of various disease-causing microbial organisms or prepared slides of cellular components of human blood)

E342610BC10C40C7A30D6F24633C2754.description: implement appropriate sampling procedures (e.g., determine the prevalence of genetic traits over several generations, using a provided pedigree)

170186887B314D19913C3E5BCD422E8D.description: PERFORMING AND RECORDING: Conduct investigations into the relationships between and among observations, and gather and record qualitative and quantitative data

BA141C3002C349A98173870DF10A24E5.description: evaluate and select appropriate instruments for problem solving, inquiry and decision making (e.g., decide what needs to be measured, and select the proper procedures and tools for the task; investigate conditions necessary for growing nonpathogenic bacteria)

9EF11B34B5534F058D3C8FCB7B89D587.description: identify questions to investigate that arise from practical problems and issues (e.g., “How effective are commercially available antibacterial cleaners on bacteria found in the home or in school?”)

D67322876ABD41A986A2F827A988235D.description: INITIATING AND PLANNING: Ask questions about relationships between and among observable variables, and plan investigations to address those questions.

3A2438C934F847EE8EF840A5B5E7B970.description: relate the advances in genetic research to ethical and social issues (e.g., the human genome project, genetic engineering, cloning, screening for genetic disorders)

7695D0C828C347E2B00D0D179A712E5C.description: assess the impact of aseptic and sterilization techniques in modern medicine on human longevity (e.g., Joseph Lister’s sterilization of operation theatres, use of the autoclave)

10088A41281D44C8AA5AC183B31DC633.description: assess the ongoing need for public health department guidelines and personal actions to maintain and improve upon the health of the community (e.g., food handling and preparation in protecting human health, quarantines, use of sewers and landfills)

5D0B7882514F41BB8C3DA30B7AC62CB0.description: describe, in general terms, the development of a specific immunization and a genetic therapy (e.g., smallpox vaccine by Edward Jenner or polio vaccine by Jonas Salk, experimental genetic therapy for cystic fibrosis)

2B8F14878384415AA9EC5D7EE7A1370B.description: Analyze how longevity in humans has increased over time as a result of a better understanding of pathogens and genetics, and improved sanitary conditions and personal hygiene

B72DDF2B5F954124B204F3C1441B045B.description: investigate factors that affect gene expression (e.g., effect of tobacco, alcohol, prescription drugs and street drugs on human embryos)

4EF04A295A1448D49DE899789ECD9139.description: describe how mutations in DNA result in specific disorders (e.g., muscular dystrophy, sickle cell anemia, Huntington’s disease)

5C50405A2E88442A966F1C1DF6410565.description: investigate the effect of mutagens and radiation on genes and chromosomes and the implications for inheritance of genetic disorders (e.g., polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), X-rays, other forms of radiation)

A581B4F16C0E4E499B2B251CADB8705E.description: identify the relationships among DNA, genes and chromosomes; and identify, in general, the structure and replication of a DNA molecule

118B73445C364A839F90FD05B19EB73D.description: interpret a pedigree illustrating the inheritance of autosomal single gene traits (e.g., Mendel’s research on pea plants)

C437FD705DDA49958E5448DC6585B73D.description: identify the role of chromosomes in determining the sex of human offspring

8751E5E6C00846B2B725B4C567ED6411.description: interpret a Punnett square to illustrate dominant and recessive monohybrid autosomal crosses

9F4F10B4B71C46CBBB8161C00B6B8D2E.description: describe the role of genes in inherited characteristics (e.g., hitchhiker’s thumb; earlobe attachment; hair, skin and eye colour)

831A57F890B242FE90C9AB862F1E85B5.description: Describe the role of genes in inherited characteristics and human health

6D84C3A17595473D8E4BE59AA6BC7EF5.description: describe how the overuse and improper use of antibiotics may lead to the development of resistance in bacteria (e.g., use of prescription antibiotics for viral infections)

BEB871EFEF164ADC8C75ACD459F4F1A2.description: explain how specific antibiotic therapies, vaccines or medications are used to treat or prevent a disease (e.g., measles, rabies, tetanus, smallpox, tuberculosis)

34C54EBB0FA24CECBFE703B4ACFA5184.description: compare forms of immunity in the human organism, and explain how immunity is established (e.g., natural and artificial immunization)

7355DBA00D54428DB6F8BE2068157748.description: describe, in general terms, how the immune system protects the body by attacking foreign or abnormal proteins

AEE9237C17EA46CE9DB86AF94257EF4E.description: identify the major cellular and chemical components of the human immune system

E8366786F349419E863C12785CA52DEE.description: investigate and explain the role of blood components in controlling pathogens (e.g., white blood cells and antibodies)

46F210CF46C24D22BAFE38F6423DC572.description: explain the role of the human organism’s physical defences in preventing infection by pathogens (e.g., skin, mucus membranes, tears, saliva, digestive system)

D91DE82DC0234F20B78E61F3094E67B9.description: Describe the natural mechanisms that protect the human organism from pathogens

61D88D3948C84405865E2C1D87B701D3.description: investigate and describe how a specific food handling or preparation process is designed to prevent microbial contamination of the final product (e.g., freezing, pickling, salting, vacuum packaging)

E53A8E33940B4198BEDCC768D49245AA.description: describe how noncommunicable diseases are transmitted and how they affect human health (e.g., food poisoning due to salmonella or E. coli; cholera; dysentery)

122AD6583CD7404A811C6B413EED1383.description: describe how different communicable diseases are transmitted and how they affect human health (e.g., cold, influenza)

5BC2F92631FA4C59ABBADBCC77278233.description: investigate and describe the conditions necessary for the growth of a specific pathogen (e.g., viruses, fungi, bacteria)

41AC59E0F0D7482DB96149DA4F41B71C.description: distinguish between communicable and noncommunicable diseases

F4A251B5C85D4082B11314CDEDDD7FB0.description: Analyze the relationship between human health and environmental pathogens

08A907705C9B4224AA08DD1A2B35D50F.description: analyze the impact of public health initiatives and maintaining high standards of personal hygiene in fostering healthier societies and individuals (e.g., provision of potable water, clean air standards, treatment of human and animal wastes, safe handling of food)

B290DD7E2CAF4EA0A90D206E512C285D.description: trace, from a historical perspective, the connection between diseases and contaminated drinking water, air pollution and personal hygiene

9C95AB60F3AC42708139CF228C2FEA0C.description: list the social and economic impact of pandemic diseases on past and present societies (e.g., Black Death; 1918 Influenza; severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS); impact of European diseases, such as tuberculosis, on Canada’s First Nations communities)

710E40B0D6E24967BC0538D3E2ECDBEE.description: analyze the relationship between social conditions and disease (e.g., hunger and malnutrition; sanitation and bacterial, viral, fungal diseases)

368C42A72A324F4585C271E4DD957F86.description: describe, in general terms, how human diseases may arise from an interaction of variables, including poor nutrition, stress, pathogens and environmental contamination

FB1F800B3D3448E2A69682C35BD22837.description: Describe how human health is affected by societal and environmental factors, and describe the need for action by society to improve human health

0B4A30FF52E345E0A35B6E2E89D4E8C4.description: Outcomes for Science, Technology & Society (STS) & Knowledge

E66D9196B3BE40F2BDF24567E606B4B5.description: Unit C: Disease Defence & Human Health

5789AC5FBFDC43138936B77502C592A5.description: Show concern for safety in planning, carrying out and reviewing activities (e.g., assume responsibility for the safety of all those who share a common working environment, by cleaning up after an activity and disposing of materials in a safe place)

BCCFB15297634EDAA37D40B5A89540C1.description: Demonstrate sensitivity and responsibility in pursuing a balance between the needs of humans and a sustainable environment (e.g., list consequences of improving the efficiency of fossil fuel based technologies; participate in the social and political systems that influence environmental policy in their community)

2939B574F6BF420FB606B9AC58703214.description: Work collaboratively in planning and carrying out investigations, as well as in generating and evaluating ideas (e.g., participate with others in peaceful conflict resolution; share the responsibility for errors made or difficulties encountered by the group)

A9EC2BA182124834A83D19E10BFE0F2A.description: Seek and apply evidence when evaluating alternative approaches to investigations, problems and issues (e.g., expend the effort and time needed to make valid inferences; critically assess their opinion of the value of science and its applications)

C4B317F01DF94131A31B6F9F1BD467FD.description: Appreciate that scientific understanding evolves from the interaction of ideas involving people with different views and backgrounds (e.g., consider social and cultural contexts when discussing body images; recognize the contribution and skill of technologists in extracting oil from the oil sands)

AFBCDBDE3F784B95A44342EF2054167B.description: Show interest in science-related questions and issues, and confidently pursue personal interests and career possibilities within science-related fields (e.g., research answers to their own questions, such as “How could I reduce my personal energy consumption?”)

B3D3F2EC670E4EA4991B418ED9A75BAC.description: work cooperatively with team members to develop and carry out a plan, and troubleshoot problems as they arise (e.g., develop a plan for using energy more efficiently in their school or community)

B9C8E3C7C836460BB92A513B25DDA9F0.description: select and use appropriate numeric, symbolic, graphical and linguistic modes of representation to communicate ideas, plans and results (e.g., calculate the efficiency of a basic energy system)

C55EDE3FC306490B9E4832AB729320AD.description: communicate questions, ideas and intentions; and receive, interpret, understand, support and respond to the ideas of others (e.g., collect and display data on household energy consumption, by reading and recording data from the electricity and gas meters over a two-week period)

DBE5592A028840B0B62318A7D44A2823.description: Communication and Teamwork: Work collaboratively on problems; and use appropriate language and formats to communicate ideas, procedures and results

4F928130CE0044A8BDA3E19148E61CC0.description: evaluate a personally designed and constructed device on the basis of criteria they have developed themselves (e.g., assess an energy conversion device or an artificial light technology to promote indoor plant growth)

7A9F38D143A9497E80C2587AA15FB27C.description: identify and correct practical problems in the way a technological device or system functions (e.g., redesign a model car to increase the distance it travels)

800C03C212C84351B88753219B7CF414.description: state a conclusion, based on experimental data, and explain how evidence gathered supports or refutes an initial idea (e.g., explain why the input energy in machines is always greater than the output energy)

2E632F9475104C16827D0E4134B69D4F.description: compare theoretical and empirical values, and account for discrepancies (e.g., explain the difference between the theoretical value of percent efficiency of a device and the measured efficiency in the laboratory)

FAF0C0C8B9574501A4AA512EEB0B758A.description: compile and display evidence and information, by hand or computer, in a variety of formats, including diagrams, flow charts, tables, graphs and scatterplots (e.g., report findings from an experiment to measure the power of the human body)

9A118A19FA854673B8C51F339B9DF8C5.description: Analyzing and Interpreting: Analyze qualitative and quantitative data, and develop and assess possible explanations

B01C9C2F4452401595F2B771DBCB0397.description: construct and test a prototype of a device or system, and troubleshoot problems as they arise (e.g., construct a device that uses solar or wind energy to generate electricity)

75C63234EB0843C09CC29897B5207B8F.description: select and integrate information from various print and electronic sources or from several parts of the same source (e.g., collect background information to investigate obesity, starvation or anorexia nervosa)

964E7DADDC7F46F7850F059D35D1C570.description: use library and electronic research tools to collect information on a given topic (e.g., collect data on energy requirements of individuals at varying stages of growth and levels of activity)

227F578FFA934507B8BF88CC363CF9B1.description: compile and organize data, using appropriate formats and data treatments to facilitate interpretation (e.g., list, in charts and tables, sources of energy in food)

A6330F5481C442F39E149AC93AEA7DC0.description: carry out procedures, controlling the major variables and adapting or extending procedures where required (e.g., determine the amount of thermal energy released by cellular respiration; determine the energy outputs of various foods, using simple calorimetric methods)

F478BBFA8A5B4981A84D5EA3571688A6.description: Performing and Recording: Conduct investigations into the relationships between and among observations, and gather and record qualitative and quantitative data

6282E15ADFC04D0CA76A79B0EC39E444.description: evaluate and select appropriate instruments for problem solving, inquiry and decision making (e.g., decide how to measure the energy output of a device or process, and select the proper procedures and tools for the task)

AE81F69FABFA49C183708406B3FA2704.description: propose alternative solutions to a given practical problem, identify the potential strengths and weaknesses of each, and select one as the basis for a plan (e.g., devise a plan for more efficient household energy consumption)

8D7889CB50574910BFC06EC802773B06.description: formulate operational definitions of major variables (e.g., define, operationally, power, energy and metabolism)

C87DA3AA652B4AF982CDD1B50FA871EF.description: identify questions to investigate that arise from practical problems and issues (e.g., “How can we measure the power of the human body?”)

9FEF9B06A01348319F258ED47FE27833.description: Initiating and Planning : Ask questions about relationships between and among observable variables, and plan investigations to address those questions

4E4EC56CEC3048F0A7646B24E12222C8.description: describe the importance of combustion reactions to a modern industrial society, and describe the implications of depleting fossil fuel reserves

D7A1A3C367DE42C6A8DFB9D2930E0A2D.description: assess the impact of fossil fuel based technologies on the environment

10B5ACFE77244392850864FFADA7DEAE.description: describe the sources of fossil fuels; and describe, in general terms, the extraction and refining processes used to provide people with fossil fuels

C319CA4599F24652B0A160D0C76B4022.description: compare present fossil fuel consumption by industry, homes and automobiles with projected consumption in the future

F834F51E2F6F4A7D8E37B1190A10C9AA.description: explain the importance of the fossil fuel industry in Alberta in meeting energy requirements

9C44FEB2FA054E1086B13737DFCB377A.description: Analyze and describe the impact of fossil fuel based technologies and their importance in meeting human needs

38831448AE764BF8A088AB914E751EBA.description: compare combustion of a fossil fuel with cellular respiration

C4E5007E724E482E9EFC650865CB049B.description: outline, in general terms, the formation of the following fossil fuels: oil, coal and natural gas

D835B4627BAF46389B32183C54E1618A.description: describe the factors that affect metabolism (e.g., age, level of fitness, time of day, exercise/activity), and compare daily energy requirements of individuals at various stages of growth and activity levels (e.g., energy requirements of a newborn, teenager, office worker and labourer; energy requirements while sleeping, running)

19595213B6BC4E63AEC509F4D18C4A45.description: identify the sources of energy in food as carbohydrates, fats and proteins; and explain, in general terms, why there needs to be a balance between food intake and energy output

C89F9968142C463D94A941E080A8BA64.description: describe food as fuel for the human body in meeting its needs for normal metabolic functions, exercise, and growth or repair of cells

3A5C01F3BABF4ADDAAC1E3CFD75CD2FF.description: explain, in general, the process of respiration in which glucose and oxygen are converted to energy, carbon dioxide and water

FB5E23289C4742A68BBE068DB66B85EC.description: list and explain the requirements of photosynthesis as carbon dioxide, water, chlorophyll in chloroplasts and sunlight; and list and explain the products as oxygen and glucose

A7DE2A149A6C4218811F2B7DE3672C5B.description: investigate and describe common chemical reactions that produce or absorb energy (e.g., light and heat given off by the combustion of fossil fuels, cold and hot packs)

6994D3BDFC844E4C96327701F031D66E.description: Investigate and describe the energy conversions associated with change in chemical and biological systems

40759692FBE64B34BDB2AA2CEE1FB586.description: devise a plan for making more efficient use of household energy conversion devices (e.g., doing a full load in a dishwasher or clothes dryer, using appropriate wattage light bulbs or compact fluorescent light bulbs)

78FDF58F0E264DB1BA63D2D6077B5AC9.description: define the rate of energy transfer as power, using E = Pt; identify the units of power as joules (J)/second or watts (W); and identify the units of energy as joules or kilowatt hours (kWh)

8D4B265322664104A8D41EE90117D7F3.description: explain why the useful output energy in machines is always less than the input energy

C316770711674AA68471DD5418446DC1.description: describe the efficiency of an energy conversion system as a ratio of total input energy to useful output energy, and quantify efficiency as: % efficiency = useful output energy ÷ total input energy × 100

75557DAF3AFE400C9C1B454FDA67C961.description: compare the efficiency of electrical power distribution systems by tracing the energy conversions that occur in a variety of household devices (e.g., power tools; electric cars; microwave and conventional ovens; fluorescent, incandescent and halogen light bulbs)

A3CDD2A4F36C4C7CA19B6E590951AE04.description: describe electrical power generation in terms of converting thermal/hydro/wind/solar/nuclear energy into electricity

3FBC018D7FB344E88EB107656B21983A.description: Investigate and analyze electrical energy conversion devices in terms of energy conversions, rate of energy transfer and efficiency

255C77E586B942A78F243F470F1ECB13.description: apply the law of conservation of energy to trace energy transformation, dissipation and availability in physical and technological systems (e.g., swinging pendulum)

E5C3F244CF5B461DA65A03893BD0B25A.description: describe an energy transformation system in terms of input, converter and output (e.g., an electric kettle)

62D5035C63C64995B5C998040B570136.description: design, construct and evaluate a simple model or device that transforms energy from one form to another (e.g., windmill, water wheel, model vehicle powered by rubber bands/mousetraps/carbon dioxide/electric motor)

94438BA9FA5E41829AF3FD4D1A267133.description: investigate and describe evidence of energy transformations in the home and everyday contexts (e.g., simple machines, electrical devices, chemical reactions)

C9C0B922183F46039EC24A5E80E597C3.description: Investigate and interpret transformation and conservation of various forms of energy in physical and technological systems

57AFB67CCBDA4D9AA2A5CA7F829E67A9.description: Outcomes for Science, Technology & Society (STS) & Knowledge

3DA413F746224B20BD6CCBEB469DFC90.description: Unit B: Understanding Common Energy Conversion Systems

926DD627FB2E44C9890AFAF41F233BEA.description: Show concern for safety in planning, carrying out and reviewing activities (e.g., write safety and waste-disposal concerns into a laboratory procedure; seek assistance immediately for any first-aid concerns, such as cuts, burns or unusual reactions)

390F809F22DD40E1B1EE7305F42F2381.description: Demonstrate sensitivity and responsibility in pursuing a balance between the needs of humans and a sustainable environment (e.g., walk rather than drive to neighbourhood stores to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases; assume part of the collective responsibility for the impact of humans on the environment)

2E792908DE0A4768B65D6E9E57D1E6CC.description: Work collaboratively in planning and carrying out investigations, as well as in generating and evaluating ideas (e.g., accept responsibility for any task that helps the group complete an activity; be attentive when others speak; share responsibility for errors made or difficulties encountered by the group)

6797B8D9DEF34942901BAA9A9212029E.description: Seek and apply evidence when evaluating alternative approaches to investigations, problems and issues (e.g., evaluate liming of lakes as a long-term solution to acid deposition)

94CB6F9D9EF04B9383F634C112C18F56.description: Appreciate that scientific understanding evolves from the interaction of ideas involving people with different views and backgrounds (e.g., recognize the contribution of chemistry and technology to the progress of civilizations)

7BEE6341D9534DC489C52F2FFA7F42FF.description: Show interest in science-related questions and issues, and confidently pursue personal interests and career possibilities within science-related fields (e.g., maintain interest or pursue further studies in science; explore where further science- and technology-related studies can be pursued; recognize that part-time jobs require science- and technology-related knowledge and skills)

12F79EC5A432409189BA7424EDF8D320.description: evaluate individual and group processes used in planning, problem solving, decision making and completing a task (e.g., assess processes used to construct a device that reduces CO emissions)

95D66B36D609444A8D3CACF282041912.description: work cooperatively with team members to develop and carry out a plan, and troubleshoot problems as they arise (e.g., develop a plan, seek feedback, test and review it, make revisions, and implement it)

D8CEAD3EFB55485A84684D92640A2D6F.description: select and use appropriate numeric, symbolic, graphical and linguistic modes of representation to communicate ideas, plans and results (e.g., write word equations and name simple compounds, using correct conventions)

85412DB178C2462E9D54C1591606FCAC.description: communicate questions, ideas and intentions; and receive, interpret, understand, support and respond to the ideas of others (e.g., use appropriate communication technology to elicit feedback from others)

D18EE98F0DDA4FD4A7FF20CEC132E610.description: Communication and Teamwork: Work collaboratively on problems; and use appropriate language and formats to communicate ideas, procedures and results

3E4BF62A262841ECAA136320DC382D4E.description: identify and evaluate potential applications of findings (e.g., identify ways to control corrosion of oil pipelines and equipment used in pulp and paper mills)

D7EF5E1A168A4BF8B7120FF14785EBFA.description: identify new questions or problems that arise from what was learned (e.g., “What is the possibility of drastic climate change due to global warming?”)

50556E867001490C808FBE82EF769CBB.description: identify and correct practical problems in the way a technological device or system functions (e.g., suggest ways to reduce air pollution or rusting)

C6D3766A044A477FB4A7137D8FCD725B.description: state a conclusion, based on experimental data, and explain how evidence gathered supports or refutes an initial idea (e.g., report on the results of an investigation into the effectiveness of antacid tablets)

7A098DDDBB334A0CB507B7D84FB0C9DD.description: apply criteria, including the presence of bias, to evaluate evidence and sources of information (e.g., evaluate information on technologies used to reduce emissions that cause acid deposition)

86E60E5D2B644C638B95DB5E78DC0AF4.description: compile and display evidence and information, by hand or computer, in a variety of formats, including diagrams, flow charts, tables, graphs and scatterplots (e.g., report findings of investigations of chemical change)

9E4D4DDB2FCC4D5F84EA5C914F2460CE.description: Analyzing and Interpreting: Analyze qualitative and quantitative data, and develop and assess possible explanations

287C20B3AA7F4214A70583CC8168DA99.description: demonstrate a knowledge of Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS) standards, by selecting and applying proper techniques for handling and disposing of laboratory materials (e.g., recognize substances, circumstances and actions that may be hazardous to people and the environment)

9D097E6602A241748AF1E8193DD22C4E.description: construct and test a prototype of a device or system, and troubleshoot problems as they arise

96EC693460F74A5D8344FB7C1B6D922C.description: select and integrate information from various print and electronic sources or from several parts of the same source (e.g., prepare an inventory of useful chemical substances used in a typical day, and classify them in categories: acids, bases, salts, alloys and polymers)

D1958C2D23CC4FF3AD861BE9BAE4B660.description: use library and electronic research tools to collect information on a given topic (e.g., describe the functioning of automobile technologies used to reduce harmful emissions)

160CB5E2C4D14C2F91684EA987E716C2.description: compile and organize data, using appropriate formats and data treatments to facilitate interpretation (e.g., write word equations for chemical reactions investigated, and record what was done or observed, using appropriate methods)

4DCABA4469954CD29D7C55BB2CD3F3E8.description: carry out procedures, controlling the major variables, and adapt or extend those procedures where required (e.g., investigate chemical reactions for evidence of chemical change)

76FF298D849B4C1295CB510412FA3E5F.description: PERFORMING AND RECORDING: Conduct investigations into the relationships between and among observations, and gather and record qualitative and quantitative data

F3F15A252012468F8413A679548A7BB5.description: evaluate and select appropriate instruments for problem solving, inquiry and decision making (e.g., select appropriate laboratory equipment to investigate the effectiveness of antacid tablets)

C21204CB2C614B5590FBB2A3F1B02B8A.description: propose alternative solutions to a given practical problem, identify the potential strengths and weaknesses of each, and select one as the basis for a plan (e.g., propose and assess ways to reduce car exhaust emissions into the atmosphere)

FD722F310C1E457292902667DDCA573C.description: identify questions to investigate that arise from practical problems and issues (e.g., “What environmental factors affect rusting the most?”)

581BCD1FDEDC4528A1B6B610BE100996.description: INITIATING AND PLANNING: Ask questions about relationships between and among observable variables, and plan investigations to address those questions

D93351BFF9D6429198EB28BDB5245065.description: investigate and describe technologies used to reduce emissions that cause acid deposition

7F887559578742A5989D93DCCF50D634.description: investigate and describe greenhouse gases and air pollution resulting from combustion reactions (e.g., carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide released when methane is burned in a household furnace, sulfur dioxide and nitrogen dioxide released in car exhaust)

9A939F3BADC34717ACB9E71E26275A03.description: provide examples of how technology has addressed the problem of corrosion (e.g., protecting with paint, oil, plastic or metal; using alloys or sacrificial metals)

9D813B2272D24DD593AA5435ABD4D4EE.description: investigate and describe simple chemical processes occurring in everyday life (e.g., acid–base reactions in cleaning and food processing, dyeing of hair, washing of clothes, burning of gasoline in a car engine, swimming pool maintenance, rusting of metal)

BFA0A97854744F69ABC2995911CE5E8E.description: analyze and explain common acid–base neutralization reactions (e.g., neutralization of stomach acid by antacids, use of baking soda or baking powder, use of lemon juice on fish dishes)

FFC42BBFBF084530A32F380E31FED268.description: Analyze common technological products and processes encountered in everyday life and careers, and analyze their potential effects on the environment

7E087CC6F821408E922CEF076256A894.description: design an experiment to illustrate that mass cannot be created or destroyed in a chemical reaction

99A21964393B488E911E455274606604.description: represent simple chemical reactions (e.g., neutralization, combustion, simple composition, decomposition) using word and/or balanced chemical equations

E35636BA08D34B09A23FEF3B7454BC1D.description: relate the concept of the atom to the conservation of mass; i.e., the number of atoms stays the same as they are rearranged in a chemical reaction; therefore, the total mass before and after the reaction remains the same (e.g., analyze the chemical equation 2Mg(s) + O2(g)→ 2MgO(s) to illustrate the law of conservation of mass by counting the number of atoms of each element)

0192D7296ECE47EC9ED273F516CACF66.description: Explain the law of conservation of mass when balancing chemical reactions

6AB13F87D99D4DF194C3284A81941464.description: identify simple composition, decomposition, combustion and neutralization reactions when given word and/or chemical equations, products and reactants

5FF296F465F44221834FE22A42868FFD.description: describe, using observation, the chemical properties of reactants and products in chemical reactions (e.g., neutralization, combustion, simple composition, decomposition)

1313CDD67FD5455F94A9FED7DDD1CB42.description: investigate and describe simple composition and decomposition reactions (e.g., tarnishing of silver, electrolysis of water)

AD38E3B5BAD7407A8119FD3D3AF244D8.description: define, operationally, endothermic and exothermic reactions (e.g., mixing chemicals in a “cold pack,” burning natural gas)

1A4B2F4D3B114E0480B922AF217E7B71.description: investigate, describe and compare the changes to reactants and products in fossil fuel combustion and rusting reactions

4F8E2A7D8D5B485C9986752A45093C5B.description: investigate evidence of chemical change; i.e., change of phase, appearance, colour, odour, energy (e.g., heat, light)

3DC6132E4C1945A18B25DCCE6DAF1CFB.description: infer the relationship among chemical formulas, composition and name (e.g., simple acids, bases, salts)

71D202AA026243E3A6A4D281270AE8BF.description: name simple compounds from chemical formulas, and recognize the chemical names of substances that are used every day

71A0EE1349DD499DA9D4C1B0927284C5.description: identify examples of chemical changes involved in cooking, cleaning, personal care and gardening (e.g., acids in vinegar, citrus fruits and rhubarb react with aluminum kitchen utensils; bases in drain cleaners react with grease; emulsifiers and softeners are ingredients in skin creams; pesticides interfere with metabolic processes in living systems)

6B05A9109B3347629A0BD13B174A6E02.description: identify common materials and their uses, and describe how everyday life has changed over the past 100 years with the development of new materials (e.g., acids, bases, alloys, plastics, ceramics, fibres, composites)

54176837A82048C8AADDC32704F17889.description: Describe how everyday life depends upon technological products and processes that produce useful materials and energy

990908661ADB41718576484A6C44022F.description: Outcomes for Science, Technology & Society (STS) & Knowledge

2D8176287734419FA27D55E28DED7066.description: Unit A: Applications of Matter & Chemical Change
